content.description: Sit start with an incut left hand edge and a right hand jug/sidepull. From there, pull up to a pair of good edges, then work through a series of small crimps to reach a good edge below the lip. At that point, finish the problem on good bumps.
content.protection: A pad or two will work fine, the landing is flat and clear.
content.location: It climbs to the right of the juniper tree on Chinese Algebra's south face.

content.description: Start low, and climb straight up the slight overhang.
content.protection: Pads. This has a great landing.
content.location: It climbs the northeast face of Mecca.

content.description:
Sit start with hands matched on an obvious, low edge. From there, traverse slight right using a pair of slopers and pastey feet, then head up the center of the slab by using the edges to reach a jug before the lip and an eventual easy mantel.

I found the slab section is more easily done by staying slightly right of the beta line found on the page's photo.
content.protection: Pads. This has a great landing.
content.location: It climbs the west face of Mecca.

content.description: Sit-start on large crimp rail with smeary feet.  Move right to good holds and then up and back left.  Make a long move from a good right hand hold up and to the left to a good hold and then the BOSS.  Top out easily from here.
content.location:
This is on the North/Northwest face of Chinese Algebra Boulder... right of

Chinese Algebra

.

content.description:
Sit start with hands on a pair of horizontal edges.  From there, work up the left side of the arete on generously-sized patina edges. Once at the lip, top it out left of the scoop using the bumps

Variation also exists by climbing the arete on the opposite side.
content.protection: A pad should do it, the landing, as the name implies, is a pillowy dust that makes for a soft landing.
content.location: It climbs the left side of the east arete on the Mecca Boulder.

content.description: Start low, traverse left along the south face, round the corner, continue along the lip to the nose, and head up for the finish.
content.location: It traverses along the south face to the west face of Mecca.

content.protection: Pads. The landing is good but sloping.
content.location: It climbs the northwest arete of Mecca.

content.description:
Sit start with a low, obvious edge. From there, traverse right to the lip, then finish up the edges for an easy mantle.

I'm keeping with the original poster's grade for the page. But I feel like the start section and traverse to the lip are more likely V3 in difficulty, the remaining slab is consistent with the V1 grade though.
content.protection: A pair of pads. The landing is very good.
content.location: It climbs the west face of Mecca.

content.description: Sit start matched on the feature below the lip. From there, come out to the lip, then finish straight up the featureless slab.
content.protection: A pad or two. This has a good landing though.
content.location:
Do the same start as

Chinese Algebra

, and climb the west face of Mecca.

content.description:
A classic sloper problem for the Nine Mile Hill.

Start low on the left side of the west face on a slopey, half-triangular hold. Figure out how to pull on it, and go out left onto the sloper rail. Heel hook and continue to slap up the rail with that left hand until you think you can stick that right hand on and contain it. Stick it and figure out a way to get up and over the bulge. As does with most sloper problems - temperatures can make or break you. Easier come winter time, harder in the heat of summer.

GRADE THIS PROBLEM PEOPLE!!!

Some say V5, most say it's V6.
content.protection: None - great landing - not very high off the deck.

content.description: Start low, traverse left to the arete, then head up for the finish.
content.protection: A few pads will do. The landing is good, but the finish has a good-sized rock behind it.
content.location: It climbs the south face of Mecca.

content.protection: Pads. This has a good landing.
content.location: It climbs the northeast face of Mecca.

content.description: Start low just a bit left of the tree on a slanting edge and a crimp. Make your way a bit left and then straight up on crimps and perhaps a sloping sidepull. Find the good hold near the lip, and then grasp a glorious horn over the lip. It is balancy and reachy.
content.protection: Pad, it has a pretty good landing.
content.location: It is on the west or southwest face of Chinese Algebra Boulder, just left of a lone tree.
